meanings.definition: To cause someone to lose confidence or enthusiasm.
meanings.sent1: His harsh criticism can discourage students from trying new things.
meanings.sent2: The coach didn't want to discourage the team, so he offered words of encouragement.
meanings.sent3: She joked that her cooking skills might discourage even the bravest of taste testers.
meanings.sent4: The storm clouds looming overhead seemed to discourage any hope of a sunny day.
meanings.sent5: The teacher's kind words were like a shield against anything that could discourage her students.

meanings.definition: To try to prevent or prevent someone from doing something.
meanings.sent1: The warning signs are there to discourage people from entering the dangerous area.
meanings.sent2: The locked gate is meant to discourage trespassers from entering the property.
meanings.sent3: The loud alarm was set up to discourage anyone from trying to steal the precious jewels.
meanings.sent4: The high fence around the garden discouraged rabbits from munching on the vegetables.
meanings.sent5: The fierce guard dog was a clear sign to discourage any unwanted visitors.

meanings.sent1: I would discourage you from taking that risky shortcut through the forest.
meanings.sent2: The doctor will discourage you from eating too much sugar for the sake of your health.
meanings.sent3: Her friend's comical face was enough to discourage her from wearing that outrageous outfit.
meanings.sent4: The wise old owl's hoot seemed to discourage the young birds from straying too far from the nest.
meanings.sent5: The caution tape was there to discourage anyone from entering the construction zone.
